questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia presents to your office for a routine cardiovascular examination. During auscultation, you note a prominent heart sound immediately following the T-wave on the ECG. Referring to the heart sound indicated by the purple arrow in the provided phonocardiogram, what is the most likely cause of this sound?

A 65-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure presents to the emergency department with complaints of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue. His medications include furosemide, enalapril, and spironolactone. Laboratory tests show a serum sodium concentration of 125 mmol/L and a serum potassium concentration of 5.0 mmol/L. Using the Darrow-Yannet diagram, which of the following best represents his fluid and electrolyte status (Dotted line representing normal condition)?

In a patient with malignant hyperthermia triggered by anesthesia, which of the following alterations in the process of excitation-contraction (EC) coupling is primarily responsible for the rapid onset of muscle rigidity and hyperthermia?

options.label: A
options.text: Inactivity of L-type calcium channels in the sarcolemma

options.label: B
options.text: Overactivity of calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR)

options.label: C
options.text: Impaired release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced activity of voltage-gated sodium channels in the muscle membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. Overactivity of calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Overactivity of calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR)

questions.text: Preload is the stretching of the cardiac muscle fibres at the end of diastole, just before contraction. It is due to an increase in ventricular pressure caused by the filling of blood during diastole. An image is provided below that further supplements the findings stated above. These are expressions of?

A 72-year-old man visits his physician because he finds it difficult to hold his hand steady when painting. Examination reveals a resting tremor and rigidity. The symptoms are relieved by a single dose of levodopa. This patient’s neurological signs are most likely related to a lesion within which of the following?

A 35-year-old man visits his doctor because his wife has long complained of his snoring. He undergoes polysomnography and ventilatory response testing to ascertain the extent and cause of his sleep apnea. The activity of the central chemoreceptors is stimulated by which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in the metabolic rate of the surrounding brain tissue

options.label: B
options.text: A decrease in the PO2 of blood flowing through the brain

options.label: C
options.text: An increase in the PCO2 of blood flowing through the brain

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in the pH of the CSF

questions.correct_answer: C. An increase in the PCO2 of blood flowing through the brain
questions.explanation: Ans. C) An increase in the PCO2 of blood flowing through the brain

questions.text: A 53-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with complains of right sided weakness and jargon speech. A CT brain was ordered to rule out haemorrhagic stroke. On neurological examination, there is normal object recognition but loss of comprehension. Which of the following areas is affected?
Which of the following statements are incorrect about vasopressin?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a more powerful vasoconstrictor than angiotensin II.

options.label: B
options.text: Concentration of circulating blood vasopressin after severe hemorrhage can increase enough to attenuate reductions in arterial pressure markedly.

options.label: C
options.text: Uses adenylyl cyclase-cAMP as well as phospholipase C system.

options.label: D
options.text: Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus

questions.correct_answer: D. Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus

This altered structure is analogous to which structure found in skeletal muscle?

A motorcyclist suffered head injury 6 months back and presents with persistent memory deficits following injury. Choose the most appropriately matched option related to memory?
questions.correct_answer: C. Medial temporal lobe- Declarative memory
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Medial Temporal lobe - Declarative memory

questions.text: A 40-year-old male diagnosed with bronchial asthma since last 10 years. Pulmonary function tests are done to assess lung functions. Which of the following is true:

options.label: B
options.text: VC reduces but FEV1 is normal

questions.correct_answer: A. VC normal but FEV1 reduces
questions.explanation: Ans. A) VC normal but FEV1 reduces

questions.text: In response to an increase in GFR, the proximal tubule and the loop of Henle demonstrate an increase in the rate of Na+ reabsorption. This phenomenon is called?

Identify the hormones represented by the following:

options.label: A
options.text: A- Somatostatin B- GH C- GHRH D- IGF1

options.label: B
options.text: A- Somatostatin B- GHRH C- GH D- IGF1

options.label: C
options.text: A- IGF1 B- GHRH C- GH D- Somatostatin

options.label: D
options.text: A- GHRH B- Somatostatin C- GH D- IGF1

questions.correct_answer: B. A- Somatostatin B- GHRH C- GH D- IGF1
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A- Somatostatin B- GHRH C- GH D- IGF1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This diagram represents the Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Liver Axis , specifically the regulation of Growth Hormone (GH) and Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1) .
  • • Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Liver Axis
  • • Growth Hormone (GH) and Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1)
  • • Stepwise Explanation of Hormones in the Diagram:
  • • Stepwise Explanation of Hormones in the Diagram:
  • • A (Hypothalamus - Inhibitory Hormone) → Somatostatin Somatostatin inhibits the release of Growth Hormone (GH). It is also called Growth Hormone Inhibiting Hormone (GHIH) . B (Hypothalamus - Stimulatory Hormone) → GHRH Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone (GHRH) stimulates the secretion of GH from the pituitary. C (Anterior Pituitary Hormone) → Growth Hormone (GH) GH is released from the anterior pituitary in response to GHRH stimulation . GH promotes growth and metabolic effects. D (Liver - Target Organ Hormone) → IGF-1 GH stimulates the liver to release Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1) . IGF-1 mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, including bone and tissue growth.
  • • A (Hypothalamus - Inhibitory Hormone) → Somatostatin Somatostatin inhibits the release of Growth Hormone (GH). It is also called Growth Hormone Inhibiting Hormone (GHIH) .
  • • A (Hypothalamus - Inhibitory Hormone) → Somatostatin
  • • Somatostatin inhibits the release of Growth Hormone (GH). It is also called Growth Hormone Inhibiting Hormone (GHIH) .
  • • Somatostatin inhibits the release of Growth Hormone (GH).

  • • It is also called Growth Hormone Inhibiting Hormone (GHIH) .
  • • Growth Hormone Inhibiting Hormone (GHIH)
  • • B (Hypothalamus - Stimulatory Hormone) → GHRH Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone (GHRH) stimulates the secretion of GH from the pituitary.
  • • B (Hypothalamus - Stimulatory Hormone) → GHRH
  • • Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone (GHRH) stimulates the secretion of GH from the pituitary.
  • • Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone (GHRH) stimulates the secretion of GH from the pituitary.
  • • stimulates
  • • C (Anterior Pituitary Hormone) → Growth Hormone (GH) GH is released from the anterior pituitary in response to GHRH stimulation . GH promotes growth and metabolic effects.
  • • C (Anterior Pituitary Hormone) → Growth Hormone (GH)
  • • GH is released from the anterior pituitary in response to GHRH stimulation . GH promotes growth and metabolic effects.
  • • GH is released from the anterior pituitary in response to GHRH stimulation .
  • • anterior pituitary
  • • GHRH stimulation
  • • GH promotes growth and metabolic effects.
  • • D (Liver - Target Organ Hormone) → IGF-1 GH stimulates the liver to release Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1) . IGF-1 mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, including bone and tissue growth.
  • • D (Liver - Target Organ Hormone) → IGF-1
  • • GH stimulates the liver to release Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1) . IGF-1 mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, including bone and tissue growth.
  • • GH stimulates the liver to release Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1) .
  • • liver
  • • Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1)
  • • IGF-1 mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, including bone and tissue growth.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Somatostatin inhibits GH release , while GHRH stimulates GH release . GH acts on the liver to stimulate IGF-1 production . IGF-1 is responsible for growth effects, particularly in bones and muscles .
  • ➤ Somatostatin inhibits GH release , while GHRH stimulates GH release .
  • ➤ Somatostatin inhibits GH release
  • ➤ GHRH stimulates GH release
  • ➤ GH acts on the liver to stimulate IGF-1 production .
  • ➤ GH acts on the liver to stimulate IGF-1 production
  • ➤ IGF-1 is responsible for growth effects, particularly in bones and muscles .
  • ➤ IGF-1 is responsible for growth effects, particularly in bones and muscles

questions.text: Which of the following decreases GFR:

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease in Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in Bowmans capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.correct_answer: D. Increase in Bowmans capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: Select correct sequence:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenyl cyclase→ cAMP → PKA

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The sequence represents the cAMP-dependent signaling pathway , which is a key second messenger system used by many hormones and neurotransmitters. The correct sequence follows these steps:
  • • cAMP-dependent signaling pathway
  • • Adenyl Cyclase Activation: A G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) is activated by a ligand (e.g., epinephrine, glucagon). The Gαs subunit of the G-protein activates adenyl cyclase (AC), an enzyme present on the inner surface of the plasma membrane. cAMP Production: Adenyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP) . cAMP acts as a second messenger that amplifies the signal inside the cell. PKA Activation: cAMP activates Protein Kinase A (PKA) by binding to its regulatory subunits. This releases the active catalytic subunits , allowing PKA to phosphorylate target proteins involved in cellular responses.
  • • Adenyl Cyclase Activation: A G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) is activated by a ligand (e.g., epinephrine, glucagon). The Gαs subunit of the G-protein activates adenyl cyclase (AC), an enzyme present on the inner surface of the plasma membrane.
  • • Adenyl Cyclase Activation:
  • • A G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) is activated by a ligand (e.g., epinephrine, glucagon). The Gαs subunit of the G-protein activates adenyl cyclase (AC), an enzyme present on the inner surface of the plasma membrane.
  • • A G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) is activated by a ligand (e.g., epinephrine, glucagon).
  • • G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR)
  • • The Gαs subunit of the G-protein activates adenyl cyclase (AC), an enzyme present on the inner surface of the plasma membrane.
  • • Gαs subunit
  • • G-protein
  • • adenyl cyclase
  • • cAMP Production: Adenyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP) . cAMP acts as a second messenger that amplifies the signal inside the cell.
  • • cAMP Production:
  • • Adenyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP) . cAMP acts as a second messenger that amplifies the signal inside the cell.
  • • Adenyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP) .
  • • Adenyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP)
  • • cAMP acts as a second messenger that amplifies the signal inside the cell.
  • • second messenger
  • • PKA Activation: cAMP activates Protein Kinase A (PKA) by binding to its regulatory subunits. This releases the active catalytic subunits , allowing PKA to phosphorylate target proteins involved in cellular responses.
  • • PKA Activation:
  • • PKA Activation:
  • • cAMP activates Protein Kinase A (PKA) by binding to its regulatory subunits. This releases the active catalytic subunits , allowing PKA to phosphorylate target proteins involved in cellular responses.
  • • cAMP activates Protein Kinase A (PKA) by binding to its regulatory subunits.
  • • cAMP activates Protein Kinase A (PKA)
  • • This releases the active catalytic subunits , allowing PKA to phosphorylate target proteins involved in cellular responses.
  • • releases the active catalytic subunits

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Adenyl Cyclase-cAMP-PKA pathway is a major signaling cascade in cells. It is used by hormones like glucagon, epinephrine, ACTH, and FSH/LH . Understanding this sequence is crucial for pharmacology and physiology, especially in endocrine and metabolic pathways.
  • ➤ The Adenyl Cyclase-cAMP-PKA pathway is a major signaling cascade in cells.
  • ➤ Adenyl Cyclase-cAMP-PKA pathway
  • ➤ It is used by hormones like glucagon, epinephrine, ACTH, and FSH/LH .
  • ➤ glucagon, epinephrine, ACTH, and FSH/LH
  • ➤ Understanding this sequence is crucial for pharmacology and physiology, especially in endocrine and metabolic pathways.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male severs an artery in a motorcycle accident. A bystander applies a tourniquet to stop the bleeding. options.label: A
options.text: The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the pressure difference

options.label: B
options.text: The blood flow will be directly proportional to the radius

options.label: C
options.text: The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the length

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?

options.label: B
options.text: A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers

options.label: C

options.text: A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.correct_answer: C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
questions.explanation: Ans. C) A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers.

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?
In a patient with suspected endocrine dysfunction, which hormone primarily acts through the signaling pathway shown in the diagram below, potentially contributing to the patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leptin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The diagram illustrates the JAK-STAT signaling pathway , which is a key intracellular signaling cascade activated by cytokine receptors. The JAK-STAT pathway is primarily used by hormones and cytokines that influence gene transcription. Among the answer choices, Leptin is the hormone that predominantly acts through this pathway.
  • • JAK-STAT signaling pathway
  • • JAK-STAT pathway
  • • hormones and cytokines
  • • Leptin
  • • Leptin is a hormone secreted by adipose tissue and plays a crucial role in energy homeostasis, appetite regulation, and metabolism . It binds to leptin receptors (Ob-R), which activate JAK-STAT signaling , leading to changes in gene expression that regulate food intake and energy expenditure.
  • • adipose tissue
  • • energy homeostasis, appetite regulation, and metabolism
  • • leptin receptors (Ob-R), which activate JAK-STAT signaling
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Calcitonin
  • • Option B. Calcitonin
  • • Calcitonin acts through the G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) and cAMP pathway , not JAK-STAT. Its primary role is to lower blood calcium levels by inhibiting osteoclast activity.
  • • Calcitonin acts through the G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) and cAMP pathway , not JAK-STAT.
  • • G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) and cAMP pathway
  • • Its primary role is to lower blood calcium levels by inhibiting osteoclast activity.
  • • Option C. Vasopressin (Antidiuretic Hormone - ADH)
  • • Option C. Vasopressin (Antidiuretic Hormone - ADH)
  • • Vasopressin works through V1 (IP3 pathway) and V2 (cAMP pathway) receptors , not JAK-STAT . It regulates water balance and blood pressure by acting on the kidneys.
  • • Vasopressin works through V1 (IP3 pathway) and V2 (cAMP pathway) receptors , not JAK-STAT .
  • • V1 (IP3 pathway) and V2 (cAMP pathway) receptors
  • • not JAK-STAT
  • • It regulates water balance and blood pressure by acting on the kidneys.
  • • Option D. Aldosterone
  • • Option D. Aldosterone
  • • Aldosterone acts via the nuclear receptor pathway , binding to intracellular mineralocorticoid receptors (MRs) in the kidney. It regulates sodium and water retention to maintain blood pressure.
  • • Aldosterone acts via the nuclear receptor pathway , binding to intracellular mineralocorticoid receptors (MRs) in the kidney.
  • • nuclear receptor pathway
  • • intracellular mineralocorticoid receptors (MRs)
  • • It regulates sodium and water retention to maintain blood pressure.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The JAK-STAT pathway is a critical signaling mechanism for cytokines and certain hormones like leptin, growth hormone, and prolactin . Understanding these pathways is essential for recognizing hormonal dysfunctions related to metabolism and energy homeostasis.
  • ➤ JAK-STAT pathway
  • ➤ cytokines and certain hormones like leptin, growth hormone, and prolactin
